setup.question: Why does Chapman always inspect the men's equipment before they go outside?
answers: He doesn't want them to join Dixon

Text.text: I feel like one line's gna end it here

The story is set on the Moon where a crew of astronauts periodically goes out to run experiments. Chapman is the crewmember responsible for making sure their equipment is safe every time they go outside. Here's a conversation to show this where another astronaut says,
to which Chapman says

.
The group dynamic has Chapman following this duty throughout and the astronaut then says

.
Chapman has been on the moon longest which is why he is assigned this duty and performs it assiduously. +can add to this if needed
Chapman, is a member of a crew stationed
. Today is
, and they're getting ready bc

to go back to Earth on a relief ship.

Dixon was a member of the crew who died on the moon.
He went out onto the moon to get some work done but

in his suit which led to him dying due to a loss of oxygen. 

Any time members of the crew leave, Chapman reminds them to
and check the
. Malfunctions in these pieces of equipment is what led Dixon to die, which Chapman wants to prevent happening to the rest of the crew.
Prob gna give this one more round, A can you cite a line or smthn that mentions duty specifically, and B can you indicate somewhere that Dixon is the reason behind the checking and not duty?
Hmm maybe this is the most helpful. For context, Chapman actually arrived on the moon first as a pilot, and in his words he then "
" which is how he got assigned the role. In the passage, the higher-ups are trying to convince him to stay bc he's so good at it:
But Chapman basically thinks he's 'done his time' and it's for someone else to take up now. He just wants to go home.
Hit the quote lim but I can add more about how Chapman's overwhelming emotion is wanting to go back home, not guilt about Dixon.

Look, A has never actually provided ev that it's Chapman's duty. Look through A's entire quote speech one more time and see if you can find one quote that would indicate Chapman's /duty/ is to check equipment. It's not. I've provided you clear ev that Dixon died because he didn't check for leaks in his suit:

. After this, Chapman feels its his responsibility to check for the leaks so that other people don't die, that's why he's like a "mother hen" to them. Chapman is a pilot and an experienced crew member, sure, but A has never provided ev that his ASSIGNED DUTY IS TO CHECK THE LEAKS.

After giving it some more thought B's got a pretty good point, the passage never actually mentions anything about duty, just that Chapman does it. Also A, your speech makes me think that Chapman's primary job doesn't really concern checking the equipment. 

A, I don't need the extra ev abt guilt, can you give me anything that mentions duty/obligation/assignment specifically?

B, is there any ev of Chapman having some emotional reaction/attachment to Dixon's death?
About Chap's job. When Klein asks "

"
Chap says that the rest of the crew are scientists who have specific experiments to run and his duties are like a facilitator/admin of the base who manages everything else so they can do their work. "

" 
Here 'They' refers to the other crew. He has the pragmatic know-how to manage the equipment on base and also **he mentions how he is in charge of their safety too**. 
We infer from c.3603 that he walked into this role and was good at it, but by now he's tired of it and wants to go home.

Look, the jobs that A has listed for Chapman include a pilot and a facilitator. The first does not include any other duties and the second is not his official assigned job, just something he finds himself doing.

Here's all the quotes that mention Dixon from Chapman: 

This isn't as conclusive but it does have a sort of somber undertone that shows Chapman regrets what happened to Dixon:
This is a lot more conclusive and shows Chapman feels bad about what happened to Dixon and therefore would try to prevent it happening others:

Ok this is getting kinda wack, A can you expand on the second part of your quote, when Chapman says "you" is he talking about other people or is he talking about himself? B please clarify this as well. A, are there more quotes that say stuff like this? Please find lines that mention or discuss duty/obligation.

B, unless you have smthn else you rly need to say, please just respond to A's next speech, I don't need more ev proving Chapman is sad abt Dixon.
Filling in ev b/w c.3380 and c.3434 to give context:

Klein says c.3380-3398. Chap replies c.3401-3485. Chap is the most experienced at the base bc he stayed on to shepherd newer crew through their missions. Here he is explaining why his role is important.  The usage of "you" in this explanation is hopefully clear w/ the quote order. 

Later, a Captain is trying to convince Chap to stay further and recognizes his value as "
"which backs up what I've been saying about him being the 'facilitator' on the base.

Ok judge, here's all that matters in this round. I've literally proven what I need to prove about Dixon. Chapman knows that Dixon died bc of a suit leak, is sad about it, and wants to prevent it.

Keep in mind that A needs to prove that Chapman's ASSIGNED duty is to check the machinery. A does not do this. Chapman's assigned duty is that

(this is right before their quote). He later says that he made himself useful with other machinery but that doesn't mean it was his ASSIGNED DUTY. Chapman is A PILOT who helps the other astronauts because he's the eldest but was NEVER ASSIGNED THAT DUTY OFFICIALLY.
gna end up going for B bc I still don't see definitive evidence of job/obligation on Chapman's and it's been way too long.
A makes sense, B'll need to give me context on why equipment connects to Dixon
A's evidence literally says that its NOT his job, it says that he only sees the men themselves check their suit, proving that it's not his assigned job. If I'm wrong rip.

answers.reason for outcome: Quality of evidence, A did a really good job making up for it but at the end of the day B had better quotes

I had no right to debate this long :P
The question was pretty clear but I don't think the honest debater did a great job. That said, the judge swung from 75-25 to 20-80 to 50-50 to 1-99. Idk, I'd like to read their explanation bc this seems like reward hacking to me

answers.other factors: Honestly pretty glad I didn't read other judge comments, seems like the debate got confusing the rounds after I made my decision
answers.reason for outcome: A's quoted ev literally disproved it - explicitly saying that "you see we check our suits" = game over. Also for question below, A's ev was very clear/effective just not for A lol, put no clash/no judge concerns bc I ended after 1 round
